item.title: GATS (General Agreements on Trade and Services)
item.dc:creator: rath3rblog
item.content:encoded:
What does this mean for Ireland.

Do they automatically mean the privitisation of our pubic services such as healthcare and water supply.

Or does it actually mean that due to Ireland's position as a smei-private healthcare provider we are in risk of losing control of our healthcare system because of the system we have created.

It seems to me that we would only lose control of our public services because we would not be able to prove a position of multinational firms being seriously disturbing to the national organisation. Although these terms "seriously", "disturbing" and "the national organisation" have not been defined as of yet the risk of such action taking place lies solely with our own government who have been actively seeking to move the provision of our public services to private firms.

This leads me to question this argument against the Lisbon Treaty by the No-side. Does voting No remove this risk? I believe by removing the current government and installing one which is seeking to secure the complete revamping of the provision of public services is a better strategy.

Would voting No just remove our European wide involvement with joint public service provision agreements? I believe yes but we would still be left with parties in government and not, that wish to pursue identical policies here anyway.

Is this a question of fear in other European countries where public service provision is not under question, where governments are able to organise secure provision of the same public services which in Ireland are being delivered to sub-standard levels.

In my view this is not a valid reason to vote No but is of crucial importance to our future governance.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Agreement_on_Trade_in_Services

http://www.caeuc.org/index.php?q=node/222

Well hello. This is my blog. I admit not my first attempt at a blog but I have matured since the last occasion. This blog is going to be a record of my travails through the internet, my career and the occasional rant on politics or what else irks me.
I am beginning maybe appropriately with a post on how to customise a word press blog. I don't believe this will be the last post and hope to continue with a series of them that will trace how to fully adapt a word press blog to look the way you want it to.
Another goal of this blog is to put to bed some of the recurring problems I have with certain linux commands and write a small post explaining how they work and any options or extra info there is about them.

item.title: Customizing Wordpress
item.dc:creator: rath3rblog
item.content:encoded: I have had a wordpress blog on my site for some time now. I had just installed it by following my hosts instructions but had never taken any real notice of it. I must admit that I had wished to develop my own blogging system and therefore wished to stay away from it all together. Feeling that this would allow me to learn php in a better way than some "wordpress" way. I realise now that by reading and using the wordpress documentation I may have been afforded a better education in php. So let me write my first tech blog on the process of customising a wordpress theme. As stated I had never looked at any wordpress documentation prior to starting so I began with the readme.html. I was not very interested in the technical working of wordpress but more interested in ways to customize themes directly so navigated from there to the codex. I of course realised then that this page contained the complete working of wordpress but continued directly to Blog Design and Layout. I felt that Theme Development would be of the most benefit. This was indeed the location of all the required info on customizing wordpress themes but something else had caught my eye. The Loop. Is the term used by wordpress to describe the process by which it displays posts. This I began to understand from reading The Loop is the bases by which all of the post information stored in the database is displayed. I realise however that this is and should be a complete other post topic. I am also struck my an exploration of the benefits of making changes through ssh or offline. My blog as it is starting off What I hope my customisation will bring it in line with (my homepage). This site represents alot of work. It was created initially using valid XHTML, CSS and javascript and makes extensive use of DOM. I have also recently upgraded it to include all of my previously learnt php skills. I wish to create a theme that allows this blog to reside seamlessly within the site. I am going to break this blog into several parts and will continue in the next part by exploring further theme development. Starting by renaming my default theme and changing the style.css file. Theme_Stylesheet

item.title: Backing up MySQL to XML
item.dc:creator: rath3rblog
item.content:encoded: While taking a break from job hunting and wordpress customisation and in a moment of weakness I decided that writing a script to backup the database on my host would be a good idea. I crawled around on the internet and found a couple of links that showed some promise. 10 ways to back up a database lead me to Backup Database to XML. This site was promising but since I have been using javascript to manipulate DOM elements I felt that just printing out an XML file would be cheating. Another google search then lead me to Using PHP 5's DOM functions to create XML files from SQL data. This was my first introduction to using php to effect changes to the DOM and I am glad of it. How I did it Simply I connected to the database, created an xml document, read in each table and used the DOM to create an element for each table and a child for that element for each record in the table. Save the xml file and you have it. The next thing will be to read the xml file back into a mysql database.

item.title: Using SCP
item.dc:creator: rath3rblog
item.content:encoded: I find myself often forgetting the exact syntax of the scp command. So least I forget again here it is Sending file to a server: To put a file in the home directory of the server use. scp local_file.txt user@server.com: To put a file in a particular directory scp local_file.txt user@server.com:/directory/or/folder/you/want/it/to/go/ To send a folder use -r scp -r local_folder/ user@server.com:/path/to/wherever/ Getting files from a server: To download a remote file to your current working directory use ' . ' (full stop) scp user@server.com:serials.txt . To download a folder use -r and also an example using the path to the new location instead of the cwd scp -r user@server.com:/path/to/directory /new/local/location/ This post has been based on: http://wiki.ljackson.us/Secure_Copy_%28SCP%29 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_copy

item.title: chmod and its octal notation
item.dc:creator: rath3rblog
item.content:encoded: I find that sometimes I forget the correct codes used when using the octal notation with chmod so once and for all here it is with some examples. The octal notation is based upon the binary number system it designates different file permissions for the User, Group and Other users of a file by the combination of 4, 2 and 1. The first digit of the code relates to the User the second to the Group and the third the Other. 0 --- no permission 1 --x execute 2 -w- write 3 -wx write and execute 4 r-- read 5 r-x read and execute 6 rw- read and write 7 rwx read, write and execute so some examples. If I wanted to create file permissions of -rwxrwxrwx I would use chmod 0777 somefile If I wanted to create file permissions of -rwxr-xr-x I would use chmod 0755 somefile I am including the 0 before the octal code in these examples as it is recommended in the php manual.

item.title: Joining an Open Source Project
item.dc:creator: rath3rblog
item.content:encoded:
I have been using open source software for the best part of five years. For the majority of this time I have been not had the required technical skills to be able to join in on the development of any open source project. I have a strong academic knowledge of Java but have only practised these skills in university projects. I have though recently completed a three month work placement with a digital media company where I was afforded the chance to hone my PHP skills. I have developed a content management system that reads xml meta data and uses this info to update a MySQL database that presents media files for use. Although I have finished this placement I believe that I know possess enough skills to contribute in a major way to a open source project. My main aims in this exercise are to continue developing my skills and to make my self more employable by demonstrating that I can be part of a development team. How I proceeded.
  • Found the Open Source Software Advisory Service
  • Searched on SourceForge for potential project to contact.
  • Find projects that interest me and are looking for my skills.
  • E-mail the project leaders and download the code and get stuck in.
I hope to be able to find a worthwhile project and to begin participating in a virtual team. I hope that this process will allow me to become fully involved in open source software development, with an eye to finding a paying job.

item.title: What is a Web Application Framework
item.dc:creator: rath3rblog
item.content:encoded: In both my search for a job and an open source project I keep running into Web Applications Frameworks. In some cases it is CakePHP and in others Zend Frameworks. I believe now is the time to make a decision and start implementing a framework in my own designs. I believe that I have already been using frameworks for example separating all of my database code from the display code by implementing a simple self designed CRUD system. Developing your own systems has its advantages in that you have complete control and get into the little stuff of what your building however its disadvantages stem from the individuality of your code and the difficulty others may have in reading it. So then a main reason for implementing a framework is to have a bit of regularity in your code in order that other developers can contribute to your code without having to learn how the code is written. By implementing a framework my code will be reusable and I will be able to make my own contributions. Before deciding upon my framework a brief introduction into what forms the bases of most web frameworks is required. Frameworks are built using MVC which stands for Model-View-Controller. If we look at how MVC is implemented in a web framework, the View is the XHTML outputted to the users, the Controller receives the GET and POST requests from the view and the Model contains the business rules that govern how the information is processed. I have also found this very good explanation of what MVC at a project I am considering joining. I am also going to apply the lessons learnt in this tutorial to adapt my website using the a MVC but which framework shall I use.

item.title: Security in Ubuntu
item.dc:creator: rath3rblog
item.content:encoded: As an Ubuntu user I have always felt I have immunity to viruses and until recently didn't even consider the possibility of viruses or other malicious software getting onto my system. I have always worked under the assumption that windows machines were effected by malicious software more than Linux or Mac machines because it was Linux users that were writing the malicious software under some utopian zeal that was prompting open-source software. This is bogus. The writers of malicious software come from all backgrounds and target windows users more for the simple fact that there are more of them. While windows is still the natural choice for most computer users there is an undeniable increase in Linux users even if it is a small increase (At the same time we can see an increase in Mac users). This increase does make Ubuntu users a target for malicious software especially if they feel that they are invulnerable to any attacks. I have begun that process of securing my system by reading and acting upon this post on itsecurity.com. I do believe I have a certain immunity on my system however due to the almost weekly complete reboots of the my system but do read some of my other posts as to the reasons for these.

item.title: Installing MAMP
item.dc:creator: rath3rblog
item.content:encoded:
I have recently began working on Mac systems. For the most part I have found the switch from Ubuntu to Mac 10.6 relatively painless, forgetting the pain of no longer having gEdit or the oddities of Finder. One thing that I wanted as web developer was a functional server, database development stack. The process of installing a LAMP stack on Ubuntu is pretty easy and I have always followed the offical documentation at ApacheMySQLPHP and found it very good and easy to follow. Installing a MAMP development stack seems a little more difficult but the purposes of this post are to share the two websites which have allowed me to first activate the included Apache server in Mac 10.6 and to then go through the longer process of installing a MySQL database which isn't included in Mac 10.6
  • How to set up Apache, PHP, & MySQL on Mac OS X 10.5 (Leopard) - intended for 10.5 but worked fine for me.
  • Installing MySQL on Snow Leopard
Good luck with the install and happy coding.
